report_title: Industry at a Glance: Artificial Grass Turf Installation
executive_summary: The Artificial Grass Turf Installation industry includes contractors that install synthetic or artificial grass for sport applications, residential lawns or other commercial properties. Technological improvements at the manufacturing level and an increasing focus on water conservation efforts have driven revenue growth for the industry over the five years to 2020. Moreover, the industry has been supported by increased activity in construction markets for most of the current period, before the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic decimated nonresidential construction markets in 2020.

current_performance.current_performance_point_description: Because the industry's performance is closely linked to building markets and sport spectatorship and participation, the industry benefits from growing construction activity and improving economic conditions. Mounting awareness of the cost savings and environmental benefits of artificial turf products has also helped increase both the adoption of industry products and installation fees.
Accordingly, industry profit, measured as earnings before taxes and interest, is expected to reach 7.7% of industry revenue by 2020.

future_outlook.future_outlook_point_description: Over the five years to 2025, industry revenue is forecast to increase at an annualized rate of 2.6% to $3.0 billion. Improvements in both residential and nonresidential construction activity are anticipated to provide stable demand for installation opportunities as the economy recovers from the coronavirus pandemic.

Success for smaller industry operators is anticipated to become more difficult, as larger players continue engaging in merger and acquisition activity to form vertically integrated companies with manufacturing and installation divisions.

industry_definition: This industry is composed of companies that install artificial turf and synthetic grass. The industry includes installation work performed by integrated manufacturers as well as installation work done by operators that source artificial turf and grass from third parties. Manufacturing-related activities are excluded from industry calculations.

negative_impact_factors: Barriers To Entry Level - low - steady

key_trends: Demand for artificial turf and grass has expanded due to rising environmental concerns
Advancements in quality, safety and cost have opened new customer markets
Rising incomes enable consumers to trade up to higher-quality synthetic turfs
More housing developers are installing synthetic rather than natural lawns
Rising government spending on water conservation will likely benefit the industry
The vertical integration of major companies will contribute to increased profitability
The environmental benefits and cost savings of artificial turf have helped drive growth

market_segmentation.segment_description: The majority of demand for the Artificial Grass Turf Installation industry is derived from nonresidential and commercial clients. Altogether, the nonresidential and commercial segment accounts for an estimated 67.1% of industry revenue in 2020. The biggest share of this segment is derived from schools and sports fields.

Residential clients account for an estimated 15.6% of industry revenue in 2020. Homeowners are one of the fastest-growing markets for the Artificial Grass Turf Installation industry. Consumers in general have increasingly started installing synthetic grass in place of natural turf due to rising environmental awareness, product development, lower water expenses and tax rebates directed at homeowners.

The government and institutional segment generates an estimated 7.5% of industry revenue. This segment provides services to municipal governments, which require synthetic grass installation for public facilities, such as parks, and landscaping for government buildings. Local operators generally bid on these contracts, whereas residential contracts are typically marketed toward the customer.

The government and institutional segment generates an estimated 7.5% of industry revenue. This segment provides services to municipal governments, which require synthetic grass installation for public facilities, such as parks, and landscaping for government buildings. Local operators generally bid on these contracts, whereas residential contracts are typically marketed toward the customer.

products_and_services.product_description: Installation of artificial turf used for fields such as sporting and playing fields or playgrounds is the primary service segment for the Artificial Grass Turf Installation industry. In 2020, revenue from this segment is estimated to account for 62.0% of total industry revenue.

Artificial grass installation in residential areas is anticipated to account for 10.5% of industry revenue in 2020. This segment has experienced the fastest growth over the five-year period. Homeowner demand for synthetic lawns has been growing due to technological advancements, which have resulted in more natural-looking synthetic lawns.

Nonresidential artificial grass installation is estimated to account for 19.0% of total industry revenue in 2020. This segment includes grass installation for landscaping at office buildings, schools, day-care centers, road medians and airports.

Artificial turf is also installed on government property and public safety establishments. Hotels, motels, religious buildings and other recreational or amusement areas are also included. This segment operates very similarly to the nonresidential segment but often must overcome tighter budgets and red tape to switch over to artificial grass from natural grass.

tier_1_suppliers: Synthetic Fiber Manufacturing in the US
Tool & Hardware Wholesaling in the US
tier_2_suppliers: Farm, Lawn & Garden Equipment Wholesaling in the US

demand_determinants.determinant_description: Homeowners are more likely to invest in new lawn installations when there is a lower cost-to-value ratio for recouping their remodeling investment. Conversely, when per capita disposable income and housing prices are rising strongly, homeowners have a greater incentive to pursue re-installation activities to increase their overall selling price.

Demand for synthetic grass and artificial turf is also driven by legislative requirements concerning water use for businesses and homeowners. Depending on location and climate, the majority of water used by businesses and households is spent on their grass and gardens. Consequently, citywide restrictions that limit water use positively affect demand for synthetic lawns.

Technological advancements are another key factor that drives demand for synthetic lawns and artificial turf. Artificial turf is commonly made from polyethylene, polypropylene or nylon. However, over the past decade, manufacturers of artificial turf have started using polyethylene yarn rather than polypropylene because it is relatively softer and, thus, leads to fewer skin abrasions.

business_locations.location_description: The Southeast has the largest share of industry establishments, measured at 26.7% in 2020. This substantial percentage is primarily due to the region's high share of the population. In 2020, the Southeast region is expected to represent 25.8% of the nation's total population. Florida has the highest share of industry establishments with 10.4%.

The Mid-Atlantic region accounts for 13.8% of all establishments. IBISWorld estimates that this higher share of industry locations is due to the region's above-average median household income, which enables more consumers to afford trading up to higher quality synthetic grass products.
The Great Lakes region follows with 13.8% of establishments.

The West is another prominent region for industry establishments (14.1% of establishments), with California dictating trends for the region as a whole (9.1%). Heightened water restrictions and environmental concerns within the region have prompted increased homeowner and business use of artificial grass and turf. Moreover, schools in the region are increasingly switching to artificial turf, partially a result of incentives offered by local districts.

The Southwest is another prominent hub for the industry with 10.7% of industry establishments. This region has low average annual rainfall, making it susceptible to drought. Consequently, the states within the region are subject to stringent water restrictions, making synthetic lawns and artificial turf a popular choice among homeowners and businesses.

regulations_points.regulation_description: There are regulations concerning the types of materials that can be used for the infill, between the blades of grass or turf. Typically, crumb rubber, flexible plastic pellets, sand and rubber-coated sand are used as infill materials.

There are several health and safety considerations related to synthetic turf that have generated public concern, including heat stress, injury, latex allergies and chemical exposure, which owners must be aware of prior to installation.
In 2020 amid the COVID-19 (coronavirus) pandemic, industry operators were forced to operate at limited capacities for portions of the year to help curb the spread of the virus.

barriers_points.barrier_description: The competition level is high and increasing, indicating significant barriers.
However, the industry is in the growth stage with low capital intensity, concentration, technology change, and globalization levels, suggesting relatively low barriers to entry.

basis_points.basis_description: Industry operators compete heavily on the basis of price. There is a higher degree of price-based competition for residential and smaller-scale projects due to competition from homeowners and in-house teams that can perform installation work.

Quality of service is another important basis of competition for industry operators. Important quality factors include the flatness of the lawn, the use of geotextiles for standing water, appropriate overlap of the sections and evenly spread infill.

concentration_points.concentration_description: The Artificial Grass Turf Installation industry operates with a low level of market share concentration. In 2020, the top four companies are anticipated to account for less than 20.0% of industry revenue.

While there is a higher level of market share concentration for companies that manufacture artificial grass and turf, the installation sector is relatively fragmented because companies compete with small contractors, homeowners and landscape design firms that perform installation services for homeowners and businesses.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Purchases typically account for the largest expense category
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Installers of artificial grass and turf typically purchase crushed stone, seam scrim or tape, commercial-grade adhesive and chalk-line or spray paint. Other purchases also include silica sand or granulated.

cost_factors.cost_factor_title: Wages typically amount to a large expense
cost_factors.cost_factor_description: Given the service-based nature of the industry and its low capital requirements, wages typically amount to a large expense for industry operators.

capital_intensity_points.capital_intensity_description: Industry operators must purchase hand rollers or plate tamp, heavy rollers, industrial brooms, power brooms or drop spreaders for spreading and distributing infill throughout the artificial lawn and turf. In addition, companies also purchase vehicles for transporting equipment and artificial turf to site locations.
The installation of artificial turf is labor-intensive and requires skilled employees with prior industry-relevant experience.

volatility_points.volatility_description: The industry's revenue volatility in recent years has primarily been caused by the interaction between fluctuating macroeconomic conditions and growing demand for artificial turf.

technological_change_points.technological_change_description: Over the five years to 2020, tools and equipment used to install artificial turf have evolved somewhat to improve the speed and quality of work, however, the industry is primarily labor-intensive, thus the industry has not been fundamentally altered by such advancements.

There has been a significant degree of product development at the manufacturing level introducing newer and more natural-looking styles and colors, new formulations of yarn blades, antimicrobial treatments, heat reduction technology, new infill materials, and thatched styles.

FAQs.question: What industry assistance is available for artificial grass turf installers?
FAQs.answer: There is no formal tariff protection, but the industry benefits from tax rebates and grants provided to homeowners and businesses that replace natural lawns with artificial grass, primarily in arid regions like the Southwest and West to increase water conservation. Companies also benefited from the CARES Act stimulus during the COVID-19 pandemic.

FAQs.question: Do companies work with residential or non-residential markets? Can they easily switch between them?
FAQs.answer: Artificial grass turf installers work with both residential and non-residential construction markets, making it easy to switch between the two.

FAQs.question: How do companies anticipate changes in sales based on market performance?
FAQs.answer: Companies try to follow trends in the construction markets to generate revenue.

FAQs.question: What is the typical company size compared to competitors?
FAQs.answer: Companies have relatively small staffs, with the average company employing seven people.

FAQs.question: Have rising construction input prices affected profit margins recently?
FAQs.answer: Prices of key construction inputs have not significantly affected profit margins in recent years.

FAQs.question: How much do companies invest in new equipment annually?
FAQs.answer: New technology is very important to this industry, with companies investing money into new technologies for their products. However, this industry is not capital intensive.

FAQs.question: Have companies considered using new technologies to increase productivity due to rising wage costs?
FAQs.answer: Due to the nature of the industry, it is difficult to replace the highly skilled labor involved in the installation of artificial grass turf.

FAQs.question: Do companies work with trade associations? Which ones?
FAQs.answer: Companies in this industry are represented by the Association of Synthetic Grass Installers and the Synthetic Turf Council.

FAQs.question: How do companies ensure health and safety requirements are met?
FAQs.answer: Companies ensure all health and safety requirements are met by following specific safety guidelines.

FAQs.question: How do companies address seasonal fluctuations in workload?
FAQs.answer: Companies address seasonal fluctuations in work flow by efficiently managing their inventory and staff needs.

FAQs.question: What are the typical profit margins for companies in this industry?
FAQs.answer: Companies have relatively low profit margins, with average profit margins accounting for 4.0% to 10.0% of revenue.

FAQs.question: How do weather conditions and climate changes affect business demand?
FAQs.answer: It is important to be aware of the effect that climate changes, events and seasons can have on business demand, including drought and excessive rain.

FAQs.question: What quality control measures do companies have in place?
FAQs.answer: Industry operators must make sure that the materials they are using are environmentally safe and that grass and turf is properly installed.

FAQs.question: Are companies vertically integrated? How do they ensure raw material availability?
FAQs.answer: Typically, the most successful companies in the industry are either vertically integrated, with artificial grass or turf manufacturing operations, or have developed partnerships with these manufacturers.

FAQs.question: Do revenue trends follow changes in housing starts? How is demand stimulated when housing starts are low?
FAQs.answer: The industry derives revenue from the installation of artificial lawns. Hence, yard renovation is typically in higher demand when more houses are being constructed.

FAQs.question: How much business comes from residential construction companies? How can they reach more of this market?
FAQs.answer: The residential building market contributes to industry revenue through the residential artificial grass installation product segment.

FAQs.question: How do interest rates affect demand? How is demand stimulated when rates are high?
FAQs.answer: Since a majority of installations in the industry are financed with loans from commercial banks, demand for new installations is correlated with interest rates.
